What can I say? This game is absolutely fantastic not only in terms of gameplay and story, but lighting and the change of environments for its time. I can safely say this game is almost better than Half Life, if not better. The environments are much more varied, you have a sense of purpose and more of a 'clan' if you see what I mean. You can have your squad follow you (although they are relatively clumsy at times) and they are quite useful from healing you to opening doors and vents. The platforming is on touch, although the crouch-jumping is a bit awkward, but it's still a very good choice of gameplay. A perfect mix of puzzles and action. Compared to Blue Shift, this had an actual boss with weaknesses and it felt good to defeat it.

Also, I would like to add that I find the puzzles less complicated and frustrating, which may be because I've played all the other Half Life 1 parts but I see in general that they are made less complex, which is good for people like me because whilst I enjoy puzzles from time to time, I prefer shooting and puzzles should be easily solvable so you don't feel too frustrated, if you see what I mean. Still, they are perfectly challenging and it is not TOO easy to solve them, however this time I did not see myself going on the internet to find solutions. A very good game, despite a few glitches like the doors opening. The sounds are quite good for their time, but so is everything else really. A very good game that I would recommend to anyone, even those not very fond of puzzle and shooter games.

Personally, I find this the weaker expansion pack, but it's still good. The combat is stellar, but the plot makes no sense in the latter sections - though this is largely due to retcons, and not necessarily the fault of Gearbox. A good headcanon approach is to only play up to the "explosion" and assume that everything afterwards is a death hallucination (or just not play after that point.) Or if you don't care about continuity, knock yourself out and go for it all.

11/10 If you loved Half Life, you will love Opposing Force. Play as Adrain Shepard as you visit more locations in Black Mesa and fight again the second wave of the X-Race of aliens with your allies the H.E.C.U, with your goal of finding Dr. Freeman, and slowly learning what the G-Man plans to do with the Black Mesa Facility.
The only good Gearbox game.

Not as good as the Half-Life Campaign, but then again, nothing ever can be. It adds some interesting weapons and shows a great new perspective on Black Mesa and the Black Mesa Incident, even though it might not be canon. The new enemies are mediocre, however, and the final boss is just bad through-and-through. 
A necessary buy for fans of Half-Life.
Half-Life Opposing Force +

The concept is great and well executed in this game to see the same events through a different character and i wish they did the same for half life 2 but not much of the gameplay changed much. its just a different level pack with some different guns and some new mechanics. In fact this is the prime example and definition of an expansion pack. Basically not a very big leap in trying to differ itself from the first. But still fun.

Una de las mejores expansiones por no decir la mejor de Half-Life, con nuevas opciones, armas y enemigos pero manteniendo la fidelidad a Half-Life.  9/10

Yet another incredible 'add-on' game for the HL1 series. Whilst I don't feel this one has any 'proper' connection to the actual story of HL1 compared to Blue Shift, which does have a connection to it, this game gives you a wider variety of weapons, extra gameplay and the style of HL1 you would expect to see! Give it a go - you won't be disappointed if you're a HL1 fan!

This is easily the better of the 2 HL1 Expansions. 

Good points:

- introduces a few nice little mechanics like rope climbing/swinging and grappling.
- night vision goggles instead of crumby flashlight.
- some cool new enemies and weapons into the mix.
- AI team-mates are used to great effect (better than in the main game or Blue Shift)

None of this is particularly world altering in itself but it's nice to have somethings that're new and different the stir up the HL1 formula a bit.

This game has some great moments; like being trapped on a platform that's gradually collapsing into toxic goo as everything crumbles around you or fighting in pitch-black tunnels against a nest of giant alien b*****ds, that really brought back to me that unique feeling of playing HL1 for the first time 15 years ago (I only played OpForce this weekend, so a very long gap).

Bad points:

- honestly the combat can be a little obtuse at times, large numbers of bullet spongey enemies and very few resources to help you out made a pretty aggrevating combo at several points in the game.

- a few points in the game felt like they were recycling situations from the main game a little too obviously (ie. Blast Pit style boss, control artillery strikes with command console puzzle) but that isn't to take away from all the good stuff that's here.

- final boss is a bit of a rinse-repeat, rinse-repeat style slog.


Overall though if you love HL1 and haven't played this, like I hadn't, then I'd definitely recommend it; it'll scratch your nostalgia itch really nicely while also being just a different enough spin on Half Life to feel fresh.
I love it because I played it when I was young. I don't recommand if you like todays' games.

I recommend Half-Life, HL Opposing Force and HL Blue Shift all together as one experience.

Did you like Half-Life? So do yourself a favor and play this one.
It's quick, it has different aliens and weapons than the original, and it has all the great stuff that makes Half-Life such a masterpiece: puzzles, challenging battles, funny moments and a great story. 
Also, it's a great game for Half-Life fans that wish to delve deeper into the story. You'll get to meet some characters from the original game and understand the Black Mesa incident from a different perspective (and also learn a few more Black Mesa's secrets).

You know that this contribution to the Half-Life legacy isn't gonna be TOO serious when your opening cut scene features a military dude doing an R. Lee Ermey impersonation, right before he gets unceremoniously sucked out of an airplane.  It IS official Valve product, though, so while it's one of the "lighter" - and arguably less "essential" - forays into the Half-Life universe, it's still a very high-quality product by the standards of not only first-person shooters, but indeed video games as a whole.  Sure it's dated more than a tad - especially graphics and sound-wise - but the gameplay is still very much there, and the story ain't half-bad neither.  The word "solid" definitely comes to mind...and then some.  
 
   Maybe not the best place to start your FPS training - that'd be more like Half-Life itself, dare I say! - but obviously highly recommended to fans of the original who crave more.  It delivers, plain-and-simple, in a way which a far more recent "mod" like Wilson Chronicles - look it up (no, wait, don't bother) - does not.  Clever mapping, light-yet-interesting puzzles, crazy weaponry and gadgets, satisfying combat...it's all here.  An absolute steal at five dollars, really...
 
Verdict: 9.5/10.
